questions.text: Fungal Squalene epoxide is inhibited by
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Terbinafine

Highyeild:

Itraconazole inhibits 14-α-sterol demethylase Terbinafine inhibits fungal squalene epoxidase, blocking ergosterol biosynthesis. Increased intracellular Squalene also impairs cell growth. It acts as a noncompetitive inhibitor of 'squalene epoxidase,' an early-step enzyme that generates squalene epoxide converted to lanosterol and then to ergosterol by fungi. Accumulation of squalene within the fungal cells is responsible for the fungicidal action. The mammalian enzyme is inhibited only by a 1000-fold higher concentration of terbinafine.

Bouffard. It is a member of a new class of antifungals termed the echinocandins. Option: C . Itraconazole belongs to a group of medicines called antifungals. It works by stopping the growth of fungus and is used to treat infections of the mouth, throat, vagina, and other body parts, including fingernails and toenails. It kills fungi by destroying the fungal cell membrane.

Extraedge:

TERBINAFINE MOA: Terbinafine inhibits the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase. This leads to the accumulation of the sterol squalene, which is toxic to the organism. ADR: - Adverse effects are rare, - rare, consisting primarily of gastrointestinal upset and headache. - Topical terbinafine can cause erythema, itching, dryness, irritation, urticaria and rashes. Dose: One tablet given daily for 12 weeks achieves a cure rate of up to 90% for onychomycosis and is more effective than griseofulvin or itraconazole.

questions.text: Which of the following azoles is the best for treating aspergillosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Voriconazole

Highyeild:

IV amphotericin B (1.0 to 1.5 mg/kg daily) is used for invasive aspergillosis when immunosuppression is not severe. Itraconazole (200 mg 12 hourly) is useful in some less immunosuppressed patients with indolent or slowly progressive invasive aspergillosis Voriconazole is the drug of choice for invasive aspergillosis, disseminated infections caused by fluconazole-resistant Candida, Fusarium infections, and febrile neutropenia not responding to antibacterial therapy. It is also active against histoplasmosis and blastomycosis. Serious cases are first treated i.v. followed by oral voriconazole.

It works by killing the fungus that causes infections such as athlete’ s foot, Dhobie Itc h, thrush, ringworm, and dry, flaky skin. Option: C. Ketoconazole is an antiandrogen, antifungal, and anti-glucocorticoid medication used to treat several fungal infections. Applied to the skin, it is used for fungal skin infections such as tinea, cutaneous candidiasis , pityriasis versicolor, and dandruff.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with HIV comes to the physician because of an 8-day history of severe pain while swallowing. She has been hospitalized several times with opportunistic infections and has poor adherence to her antiretroviral drug regimen. Endoscopy shows extensive, white, plaque-like lesions in the proximal esophagus. The culture of a biopsy specimen grows Candida albicans. Treatment with intravenous anidulafungin is initiated. Which of the following is the primary mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decreased glucan synthesis.

Highyeild:

Echinocandin antifungal drugs (e.g., anidulafungin, caspofungin) block the synthesis of β-(1,3)-D-glucan, a fungal cell wall component. Echinocandin antifungals have a broad spectrum efficacy with minimal CSF penetration and are used for the management of both invasive aspergillosis and invasive candidiasis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Binding to ergosterol is the mechanism of action of the polyene class of antifungal drugs, which includes amphotericin B and nystatin. They have a very broad spectrum of efficacy but are not the first-line treatment for candida esophagitis. Option: C. Binding to tubulin is the mechanism of action of griseofulvin, which is used to treat a variety of superficial fungal infections (e.g., tinea). It does not play a role in the treatment of esophageal candidiasis. Option: D. Decreased DNA synthesis is the mechanism of action of the antimetabolite antifungal drug flucytosine. Flucytosine can be used for systemic fungal infections when combined with amphotericin B and is particularly useful for treating cryptococcal meningitis. It is ineffective in the treatment of esophageal candidiasis.
